title: Perceptual Analysis, Visualization and Organization of Spectral Colour Data in R
text: pavo R package developed goal establishing flexible integrated workflow working spectral spatial colour data. includes functions take advantage new data classes work seamlessly importing raw spectra images, visualisation analysis. provides flexible ways input spectral data variety equipment manufacturers, process data, extract variables, produce publication-quality figures. pavo written following workflow mind: Organise data importing processing spectra images (e.g., remove noise, negative values, smooth curves, etc.). Analyse resulting files, using spectral analyses shape (hue, saturation, brightness), visual models based perceptual data, /spatial adjacency boundary strength analyses. Visualise output, multiple options provided exploration, presentation, analysis.

what: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
title: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
text: Calculate summary variables adjacency (Endler 2012) boundary-strength (Endler et al. 2018) analyses, along overall pattern contrast (Endler & Mielke 2005).

title: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
code: adjacent(   classimg,   xpts = NULL,   xscale = NULL,   bkgID = NULL,   polygon = NULL,   exclude = c("none", "background", "object"),   coldists = NULL,   hsl = NULL )

title: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
text: classimg (required) xyz matrix, list matrices, x y correspond spatial (e.g. pixel) coordinates, z numeric code specifying colour-class. Preferably result classify(), constructed grid-sampled spectra visually modelled clustered (per Endler 2012). xpts integer specifying number sample points along x axis, evenly-spaced sampling grid constructed (required). Defaults smallest dimension classimg, though carefully considered. xscale (required) integer list integers equal length classimg() specifying true length x-axis, preferred units. required, ignored, image scales set via procimg(). bkgID integer vector specifying colour-class ID number(s) pertaining background alone, relatively homogeneous uniquely-identified backgrounds (e.g. matte background pinned specimens). Examine attributes , call summary , result classify() visualise RGB values corresponding colour-class ID numbers classified images. Ignored focal object background identified using procimg(). polygon data.frame x-y coordinates delineating closed polygon separates focal object background. required, ignored, focal object outline specified using procimg(). exclude portion scene excluded analysis, . 'none': default 'background': exclude everything outside closed polygon specified using procimg(), argument polygon. Alternatively, background relatively homogeneous colour-class ID(s) uniquely corresponding background can specified via bkgID, subsequently excluded. 'object': exclude everything inside closed polygon specified using procimg(), argument polygon. coldists data.frame specifying visually-modelled chromatic (dS) /achromatic (dL) distances colour-categories. first two columns named 'c1' 'c2', specify possible combinations numeric colour-class ID's (viewable calling summary(image, plot = TRUE) colour classified image), remaining columns named dS (chromatic distances) /dL (achromatic distances). See vismodel() colspace() visual modelling spectral data. hsl data.frame specifying hue, saturation, luminance color patch elements, might estimated via vismodel() colspace(). first column, named 'patch', contain numeric color category IDs, remaining columns specifying one 'hue' (angle, radians), 'sat', /'lum'.

title: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
text: data frame summary variables: 'k': number user-specified colour /luminance classes. 'N': grand total (sum diagonal -diagonal) transitions. 'n_off': total -diagonal transitions. 'p_i': overall frequency colour class . 'q_i_j': frequency transitions colour classes j, sum(q_i_j) = 1. 't_i_j': frequency -diagonal (.e. class-change transitions) transitions j, sum(t_i_j) = 1. 'm': overall transition density (mean transitions), units specified argument xscale. 'm_r': row-wise transition density (mean row transitions), user-specified units. 'm_c': column-wise transition density (mean column transitions), user-specified units. '': transition aspect ratio (< 1 = wide, > 1 = tall). 'Sc': Simpson colour class diversity, Sc = 1/(sum(p_i^2)). colour luminance classes equal relative area, Sc = k. 'St': Simpson transition diversity, St = 1/sum(t_i_j^2). 'Jc': Simpson colour class diversity relative achievable maximum. Jc = Sc/k. 'Jt': Simpson transition diversity relative achievable maximum. Jt = St/(k*(k-1)/2). 'B': animal/background transition ratio, ratio class-change transitions entirely within focal object involving object background, B = sum(O_a_a / O_a_b). 'Rt': Ratio animal-animal animal-background transition diversities, Rt = St_a_a / St_a_b. 'Rab': Ratio animal-animal background-background transition diversities, Rt = St_a_a / St_b_b. 'm_dS', 's_dS', 'cv_dS': weighted mean, sd, coefficient variation chromatic boundary strength. 'm_dL', 's_dL', 'cv_dL': weighted mean, sd, coefficient variation achromatic boundary strength. 'm_hue', 's_hue', 'var_hue': circular mean, sd, variance overall pattern hue (radians). 'm_sat', 's_sat', 'cv_sat': weighted mean, sd, coefficient variation overall pattern saturation. 'm_lum', 's_lum', 'cv_lum': weighted mean, sd, coefficient variation overall pattern luminance.

title: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
text: Thomas E. White thomas.white026@gmail.com

title: Run an adjacency and boundary strength analysis — adjacent
code: # \donttest{ # Set a seed, for reproducibility set.seed(153)  # Run the adjacency analysis on a single image of a butterfly papilio <- getimg(system.file("testdata/images/butterflies/papilio.png", package = "pavo")) papilio_class <- classify(papilio, kcols = 4) #> Image classification in progress... papilio_adj <- adjacent(papilio_class, xscale = 100)  # Expand on the above, by including (fake) color distances and hsl values # of colour elements in the image  # Generate fake color distances distances <- data.frame(   c1 = c(1, 1, 1, 2, 2, 3),   c2 = c(2, 3, 4, 3, 4, 4),   dS = c(5.3, 3.5, 5.7, 2.9, 6.1, 3.2),   dL = c(5.5, 6.6, 3.3, 2.2, 4.4, 6.6) )  # Generate some fake hue, saturation, luminance values hsl_vals <- data.frame(   patch = seq_len(4),   hue = c(1.5, 2.2, 1.0, 0.5),   lum = c(10, 5, 7, 3),   sat = c(3.5, 1.1, 6.3, 1.3) )  # Run the full analysis, including the white background's ID papilio_adj <- adjacent(papilio_class,   xscale = 100, bkgID = 1,   coldists = distances, hsl = hsl_vals ) #> Using single set of coldists for all images. #> Using single set of hsl values for all images.  # Run an adjacency analysis on multiple images. # First load some images of coral snake colour patterns snakes <- getimg(system.file("testdata/images/snakes", package = "pavo")) #> 2 files found; importing images.  # Automatically colour-classify the coral snake patterns snakes_class <- classify(snakes, kcols = 3) #> Image classification in progress...  # Run the adjacency analysis, with varying real-world scales for each image snakes_adj <- adjacent(snakes_class, xpts = 120, xscale = c(50, 55)) # }

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot
code: aggplot(   rspecdata,   by = NULL,   FUN.center = mean,   FUN.error = sd,   lcol = NULL,   shadecol = NULL,   alpha = 0.2,   legend = FALSE,   ... )

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot
text: rspecdata (required) data frame, possibly class rspec, contains column containing wavelength range, named 'wl', spectra data remaining columns. (required) either single value specifying range spectra within data frame combined (example, = 3 indicates function applied groups 3 consecutive columns spectra data frame); vector containing identifications columns spectra data frame (case function applied group spectra sharing identification); list vectors, e.g., = list(sex, species). FUN.center function applied groups spectra, calculating measure central tendency (defaults base::mean()). FUN.error function applied groups spectra, calculating measure variation (defaults stats::sd()). lcol colour plotted lines indicating central tendency. shadecol colour shaded areas indicating variance measure. alpha transparency shaded areas. legend automatically add legend. ... additional graphical parameters passed plot.

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot
text: Plot containing lines shaded areas groups spectra.

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot
text: Montgomerie R (2006) Analyzing colors. : Hill G, McGraw K (eds) Bird coloration. Harvard University Press, Cambridge, pp 90-147.

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot
text: Rafael Maia rm72@zips.uakron.edu Chad Eliason cme16@zips.uakron.edu

title: Plot aggregated reflectance spectra — aggplot
code: # Load reflectance data data(sicalis)  # Create grouping variable based on spec names bysic <- gsub("^ind[0-9].", "", names(sicalis)[-1])  # Plot using various error functions and options aggplot(sicalis, bysic)  aggplot(sicalis, bysic, FUN.error = function(x) quantile(x, c(0.0275, 0.975)))  aggplot(sicalis, bysic, shadecol = spec2rgb(sicalis), lcol = 1)  aggplot(sicalis, bysic, lcol = 1, FUN.error = function(x) sd(x) / sqrt(length(x)))

title: Convert data to an rspec object — as.rspec
text: object (required) data frame matrix containing spectra process. whichwl numeric character vector specifying column contains wavelengths. NULL (default), function searches column containing equally spaced numbers sets wavelengths "wl". wavelengths found whichwl given, returns arbitrary index values. interp whether interpolate wavelengths 1-nm bins (defaults TRUE). rarely recommended turn option, uninterpolated spectra incompatible downstream analyses, including notably colour vision models. lim vector specifying wavelength range interpolate (e.g. c(300, 700)). exceed.range logical. data interpolated limits specified lim lim exceeds range actual data? Useful, relatively safe, data range falls slightly within lim (e.g. 300.1 - 699 nm), produce spurious results lim far exceeds range input data. Defaults TRUE.

code: # Generate some fake reflectance data fakedat <- data.frame(wl = 300:700, refl1 = rnorm(401), refl2 = rnorm(401)) head(fakedat) #>    wl      refl1      refl2 #> 1 300 -1.3198173 -1.2601080 #> 2 301 -2.2864853 -1.4044018 #> 3 302 -0.7891444  1.8661513 #> 4 303 -0.8128883 -1.2918431 #> 5 304 -0.7274089 -0.8634225 #> 6 305  0.9984645  1.0373024  # Determine if is rspec object is.rspec(fakedat) #> [1] FALSE  # Convert to rspec object fakedat2 <- as.rspec(fakedat) #> wavelengths found in column 1 #> The spectral data contain 428 negative value(s), #>  which may produce unexpected results if used in models. #> Consider using procspec() to correct them. is.rspec(fakedat2) #> [1] TRUE head(fakedat2) #>    wl      refl1      refl2 #> 1 300 -1.3198173 -1.2601080 #> 2 301 -2.2864853 -1.4044018 #> 3 302 -0.7891444  1.8661513 #> 4 303 -0.8128883 -1.2918431 #> 5 304 -0.7274089 -0.8634225 #> 6 305  0.9984645  1.0373024

title: Bootstrap colour distance confidence intervals — bootcoldist
code: # \donttest{ # Run the receptor-noise limited model, using the visual phenotype # of the blue tit data(sicalis) vm <- vismodel(sicalis, achromatic = "bt.dc", relative = FALSE) gr <- gsub("ind..", "", rownames(vm)) bootcoldist(vm, by = gr, n = c(1, 2, 2, 4), weber = 0.1, weber.achro = 0.1) #> Calculating noise-weighted Euclidean distances and noise-weighted luminance contrasts #>      dS.mean    dS.lwr   dS.upr   dL.mean    dL.lwr   dL.upr #> B-C 4.626548 2.8682623 7.004432 7.4677171 5.7063244 9.326239 #> B-T 1.741764 0.2046389 5.015957 0.2340913 0.0339413 1.654701 #> C-T 6.110519 3.9313140 8.542214 7.2336258 5.4298695 9.082158  # Run the same again, though as a simple colourspace model data(sicalis) vm <- vismodel(sicalis, achromatic = "bt.dc") space <- colspace(vm) gr <- gsub("ind..", "", rownames(space)) bootcoldist(space, by = gr) #> Quantum catch are relative, distances may not be meaningful #> Calculating unweighted Euclidean distances and Weber luminance contrast #>        dS.mean      dS.lwr     dS.upr    dL.mean     dL.lwr    dL.upr #> B-C 0.08873222 0.058389224 0.12301039 1.11017675 0.76080437 1.5235194 #> B-T 0.02510854 0.005450728 0.07263973 0.02368528 0.00213318 0.1647769 #> C-T 0.11208967 0.081727034 0.14513597 1.06135304 0.71634168 1.4956300  # Estimate bootstrapped colour-distances for a more 'specialised' model, # like the colour hexagon data(flowers) vis.flowers <- vismodel(flowers,   visual = "apis", qcatch = "Ei", relative = FALSE,   vonkries = TRUE, achromatic = "l", bkg = "green" ) flowers.hex <- colspace(vis.flowers, space = "hexagon") pop_group <- c(rep("pop_1", nrow(flowers.hex) / 2), rep("pop_2", nrow(flowers.hex) / 2)) bootcoldist(flowers.hex, by = pop_group) #> Calculating unweighted Euclidean distances and simple luminance contrast #>               dS.mean    dS.lwr    dS.upr   dL.mean    dL.lwr   dL.upr #> pop_1-pop_2 0.0736203 0.0205342 0.2000373 0.9016919 0.7219518 1.054019 # }

title: CIE colour spaces — cie
text: vismodeldata (required) quantum catch color data. Can either result vismodel() independently calculated data (form data frame three columns representing trichromatic viewer). space (required) Choice XYZ (default), LAB, LCh colour models. visual visual system used estimating XYZ values, vismodeldata result call vismodel() (otherwise argument ignored). Options : data frame one produced containing sensmodel(), containing user-defined sensitivity data receptors involved colour vision. data frame must contain 'wl' column range wavelengths included, sensitivity cone column. 'cie2': 2-degree colour matching functions CIE models human colour vision. Functions linear transformations 2-degree cone fundamentals Stockman & Sharpe (2000), ratified CIE (2006). 'cie10': 10-degree colour matching functions CIE models human colour vision. Functions linear transformations 10-degree cone fundamentals Stockman & Sharpe (2000), ratified CIE (2006). illum illuminant used estimating XYZ values, vismodeldata result call vismodel() (otherwise argument ignored). Either data frame containing 'wl' column illuminant spectrum, one built-options: 'D65': standard daylight. 'bluesky' open blue sky. 'forestshade' forest shade.

title: CIE colour spaces — cie
text: Object class colspace containing: X, Y, Z: Tristimulus values. x, y, z: Cartesian coordinates, using space = XYZ. L, , b: Lightness, L, colour-opponent (redness-greenness) b (yellowness-blueness) values, Cartesian coordinate space. Returned using space = LAB. L, , b, C, h: Lightness, L, colour-opponent (redness-greenness) b (yellowness-blueness) values, well chroma C hue-angle h (degrees), latter cylindrical representations b CIELAB model. Returned using space = LCh.

title: Colour distances — coldist
text: Calculates colour distances. data result vismodel(), applies receptor-noise model Vorobyev et al. (1998) calculate colour distances noise based relative photoreceptor densities. also accepts colspace() data case unweighted Euclidean distances, CIE2000 distances (cielab cielch ), Manhattan distances (coc model ) returned.

title: Colour distances — coldist
code: coldist(   modeldata,   noise = c("neural", "quantum"),   subset = NULL,   achromatic = FALSE,   qcatch = NULL,   n = c(1, 2, 2, 4),   weber = 0.1,   weber.ref = "longest",   weber.achro = 0.1 )

title: Colour distances — coldist
text: modeldata (required) quantum catch colour data. Can result vismodel() noise-weighted Euclidean distances, colspace() unweighted (typically) Euclidean distances. Data may also independently calculated quantum catches, form data frame columns representing photoreceptors. noise noise calculated (ignored colspace objects): neural (default): noise proportional Weber fraction independent intensity signal received (.e. assumes bright conditions). quantum: noise sum neural noise receptor noise, thus proportional Weber fraction inversely proportional intensity signal received (quantum catches). Note quantum option work objects class vismodel. subset comparisons returned, character vector length 1 2 can provided, indicating samples desired. subset vector must match labels input samples, partial matching (regular expressions) supported. achromatic Logical. TRUE, last column data frame used calculate achromatic contrast, form depend input data indicated message execution. noise-weighted distances, noise based Weber fraction given argument weber.achro. qcatch object class vismodel colspace, argument ignored. object data frame quantal catches another source, argument used specify type quantum catch used, noise can calculated accordingly: * Qi: Quantum catch photoreceptor * fi: Quantum catch according Fechner's law (signal receptor channel proportional logarithm quantum catch) n photoreceptor densities cones used visual modeling. must length number columns (excluding achromatic receptor used; defaults Pekin robin Leiothrix lutea densities: c(1,2,2,4)). Ignored colspace objects. weber Weber fraction(s) used (often also referred receptor noise, e). noise--signal ratio v unknown, therefore must calculated based empirically estimated Weber fraction one (rarely) cone classes. noise known one receptor, typical, v applied estimate Weber fraction cones. default, value 0.1 used (empirically estimated value LWS cone Leiothrix lutea). See Olsson et al. 2017 review published values literature. Ignored colspace objects. weber.ref cone class used obtain empirical estimate Weber fraction used weber argument, single value specified. default, n4 used, representing LWS cone Leiothrix lutea. Ignored colspace objects. weber.achro Weber fraction used calculate achromatic contrast, achromatic = TRUE. Defaults 0.1. Ignored colspace objects.

title: Colour distances — coldist
text: data frame containing 4 columns. first two (patch1, patch2) refer two colors contrasted; dS chromatic contrast (delta S) dL achromatic contrast (delta L). Units dS JND's receptor-noise model, unweighted Euclidean distances colorspace models, Manhattan distances colour-opponent-coding space. Units dL vary, either simple contrast, Weber contrast, Michelson contrast, indicated output message.

title: Colour distances — coldist
text: Generic di- tri- tetra-chromatic colspace objects previously passed receptor-noise limited model return noise-weighted Euclidean distances. behaviour amended, generic spaces now return unweighted Euclidean distances. Equivalent results former behaviour can attained sending results vismodel() directly coldist() , previously, also offers greater flexibility reliability. Thus coldist() now returns unweighted Euclidean distances colspace objects (exception Manhattan distances coc space, CIE2000, distances CIELab CIELCh spaces), noise-weighted Euclidean distances vismodel objects.

what: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
title: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
text: Models reflectance spectra colorspace. information plotting arguments graphical parameters, see plot.colspace().

title: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
code: colspace(   vismodeldata,   space = c("auto", "di", "tri", "tcs", "hexagon", "coc", "categorical", "ciexyz",     "cielab", "cielch", "segment"),   qcatch = NULL,   ... )

title: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
text: vismodeldata (required) quantum catch color data. Can either result vismodel() independently calculated data (form data frame columns representing quantum catches). space colorspace/model use. Options : auto: data result vismodel(), applies di, tri tcs input visual model two, three four cones, respectively. di: dichromatic colourspace. See dispace() details. (plotting arguments) tri: trichromatic colourspace (.e. Maxwell triangle). See trispace() details. (plotting arguments) tcs: tetrahedral colourspace. See tcspace() details. (plotting arguments) hexagon: trichromatic colour-hexagon Chittka (1992). See hexagon() details. (plotting arguments) coc: trichromatic colour-opponent-coding model Backhaus (1991). See coc() details. (plotting arguments) categorical: tetrachromatic categorical fly-model Troje (1993). See categorical() details. (plotting arguments) ciexyz: CIEXYZ space. See cie() details. (plotting arguments) cielab: CIELAB space. See cie() details. (plotting arguments) cielch: CIELCh space. See cie() details. (plotting arguments) segment: segment analysis Endler (1990). See segspace() details. (plotting arguments) qcatch quantal catch metric inputted. used input data output vismodel(). Must Qi, fi Ei. ... additional arguments passed cie() non vismodel() data.

title: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
text: Smith T, Guild J. (1932) CIE colorimetric standards use. Transactions Optical Society, 33(3), 73-134. Westland S, Ripamonti C, Cheung V. (2012). Computational colour science using MATLAB. John Wiley & Sons. Chittka L. (1992). colour hexagon: chromaticity diagram based photoreceptor excitations generalized representation colour opponency. Journal Comparative Physiology , 170(5), 533-543. Chittka L, Shmida , Troje N, Menzel R. (1994). Ultraviolet component flower reflections, colour perception Hymenoptera. Vision research, 34(11), 1489-1508. Troje N. (1993). Spectral categories learning behaviour blowflies. Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung C, 48, 96-96. Stoddard, M. C., & Prum, R. O. (2008). Evolution avian plumage color tetrahedral color space: phylogenetic analysis new world buntings. American Naturalist, 171(6), 755-776. Endler, J. ., & Mielke, P. (2005). Comparing entire colour patterns birds see . Biological Journal Linnean Society, 86(4), 405-431. Kelber , Vorobyev M, Osorio D. (2003). Animal colour vision - behavioural tests physiological concepts. Biological Reviews, 78, 81 - 118. Backhaus W. (1991). Color opponent coding visual system honeybee. Vision Research, 31, 1381-1397. Endler, J. . (1990) measurement classification color studies animal color patterns. Biological Journal Linnean Society, 41, 315-352.

title: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
text: Rafael Maia rm72@zips.uakron.edu Thomas White thomas.white026@gmail.com

title: Model spectra in a colorspace — colspace
code: data(flowers)  # Model a dichromat viewer in a segment colourspace vis.flowers <- vismodel(flowers, visual = "canis") di.flowers <- colspace(vis.flowers, space = "di")  # Model a honeybee viewer in the colour hexagon vis.flowers <- vismodel(flowers,   visual = "apis", qcatch = "Ei", relative = FALSE,   vonkries = TRUE, achromatic = "l", bkg = "green" ) hex.flowers <- colspace(vis.flowers, space = "hexagon")  # Model a trichromat (the honeybee) in a Maxwell triangle vis.flowers <- vismodel(flowers, visual = "apis") tri.flowers <- colspace(vis.flowers, space = "tri") plot(tri.flowers)   # Model a tetrachromat (the Blue Tit) in a tetrahedral colourspace vis.flowers <- vismodel(flowers, visual = "bluetit") tcs.flowers <- colspace(vis.flowers, space = "tcs")  # Model a housefly in the 'categorical' colourspace vis.flowers <- vismodel(flowers, visual = "musca", achro = "md.r1") cat.flowers <- colspace(vis.flowers, space = "categorical")

title: Plot a dichromat segment — diplot

(defaults TRUE). ... additional graphical options. See par().

title: Colour hexagon — hexagon
text: vismodeldata (required) quantum catch colour data. Can either result vismodel() independently calculated data (form data frame three columns named 's', 'm', 'l', representing trichromatic viewer).

title: Colour hexagon — hexagon
text: data frame class colspace consisting following columns: s, m, l: quantum catch data used calculate remaining variables x, y: cartesian coordinates colour hexagon. h.theta: hue angle theta (degrees), 0-degrees 1200 angle, increasing clockwise. r.vec: r vector (saturation, distance center). sec.fine: fine 'hue sector', wherein full hexagon composed 36 10-degree sectors, 0-degrees 1200 angle. sec.coarse: coarse 'hue sector', wherein full hexagon composed five sectors: blue, bluegreen, green, uvgreen, uv, uvblue.

title: Colour hexagon — hexagon

title: Convert JND distances into perceptually-corrected Cartesian coordinates — jnd2xyz
text: Converts coldist() output Cartesian coordinates perceptually-corrected (.e. noise-weighted Euclidean distances)

title: Convert JND distances into perceptually-corrected Cartesian coordinates — jnd2xyz
code: jnd2xyz(   coldistres,   center = TRUE,   rotate = TRUE,   rotcenter = c("mean", "achro"),   ref1 = "l",   ref2 = "u",   axis1,   axis2 )

title: Convert JND distances into perceptually-corrected Cartesian coordinates — jnd2xyz
text: coldistres (required) output coldist() call. center logical indicating data centered centroid (defaults TRUE). rotate logical indicating data rotated (defaults TRUE). rotcenter vectors rotation centered achromatic center ("achro") data centroid ("mean", default)? ref1 cone used first reference. May NULL (first rotation 3-dimensional case) must match name original data used coldist(). Defaults 'l'. ref2 cone used second reference. May NULL (first rotation 3-dimensional case) must match name original data used coldist(). Defaults 'u'. (used data 3 dimensions). axis1 vector length number cones minus 1 composed 0's 1's, 1's representing axes (x, y, z) rotate around. Defaults c(1, 1, 0) 3 dimensions, rotation aligns xy plane, c(1, 0) 2 dimentions, rotation centered x axis. Ignored ref1 NULL (3-dimensional case ). Ignored dichromats. axis2 vector length number cones minus 1 composed 0's 1's, 1's representing axes (x, y, z) rotate around. Defaults c(0, 0, 1) 3 dimensions, rotation aligns z axis, c(0, 1) 2 dimentions, rotation centered y axis. Ignored ref1 NULL (3-dimensional case ). Ignored dichromats.

title: Perceptually-corrected chromaticity diagrams — jndplot
text: x (required) output jnd2xyz() call. arrow arrows indicating receptor vectors drawn. Options "relative" (default), "absolute" "none". See description. achro Logical. achromatic variable plotted dimension? (available dichromats trichromats, defaults FALSE). arrow.labels Logical. labels plotted receptor arrows? (defaults TRUE) arrow.col color arrows labels. arrow.p scaling factor arrows. labels.cex size arrow labels. margin accepts either "recommended", function choose margin attributes, numerical vector form c(bottom, left, top, right) gives number lines margin specified four sides plot. (Default varies depending plot dimensionality). square logical. aspect ratio plot held 1:1? (defaults TRUE). ... additional parameters passed plot(), arrows() graphics::persp() (3D plots).

title: Perceptually-corrected chromaticity diagrams — jndplot
text: Creates plot, details plot depend input data.

title: Perceptually-corrected chromaticity diagrams — jndplot
text: arrow argument accepts three options: "relative": option, arrows made relative data. Arrows centered data centroid, arbitrary length half average pairwise distance points, can scaled arrow.p argument. "absolute": option, arrows made reflect visual system underlying data. Arrows centered achromatic point colourspace, length equal distance monochromatic point (.e. colour stimulates approximately 99.9% receptor alone). Arrows can still scaled using arrow.p argument, case interpreted described. "none": arrows included.

title: Merge two rspec objects — merge.rspec
text: Chad Eliason cme16@zips.uakron.edu

title: Merge two rspec objects — merge.rspec
code: # Load angle-resolved reflectance data for a green-winged teal, and # split it in two data(teal) teal1 <- teal[, c(1, 2:5)] teal2 <- teal[, c(1, 6:13)]  # Merge the two split datasets back into one, with a shared 'wl' column teal.mer <- merge(teal1, teal2, by = "wl")  # Examine the results, and compare the original to the (identical) # reconstructed version plot(teal.mer)  plot(teal) identical(teal.mer, teal) #> [1] TRUE  # Or an equivalent method, which also allows for the merging of more than one rspec # object at a time (simply add further objects to the list()) teal.mer2 <- do.call(merge, list(teal1, teal2))  # Check equivalence identical(teal.mer2, teal) #> [1] TRUE

title: Peak shape descriptors — peakshape
text: Calculates height, location width peak reflectance midpoint (FWHM). Note: bounds set wide enough incorporate minima spectra. Smoothing spectra using procspec() also recommended.

title: Peak shape descriptors — peakshape
code: peakshape(   rspecdata,   select = NULL,   lim = NULL,   plot = TRUE,   ask = FALSE,   absolute.min = FALSE,   ... )

title: Peak shape descriptors — peakshape
text: rspecdata (required) data frame, possibly class rspec, contains column containing wavelength range, named 'wl', spectra data remaining columns. select specification spectra plot. Can numeric vector factor (e.g., sex == "male") lim vector specifying wavelength range analyze. plot logical. plots indicating calculated parameters returned? (Defaults TRUE). ask logical, specifies whether user input needed plot multiple plots number spectra analyze greater 1 (defaults FALSE). absolute.min logical. TRUE, full width half maximum calculated using absolute minimum reflectance spectrum, even value falls outside range specified lim. (defaults FALSE) ... additional arguments passed plot.

title: Peak shape descriptors — peakshape
text: data frame containing column names (id); peak height (max value, B3), location (hue, H1) full width half maximum (FWHM), well half widths left (HWHM.l) right side peak (HWHM.r). Incl.min column indicates whether user-defined bounds incorporate actual minima spectra. Function return warning .

title: Peak shape descriptors — peakshape
text: Chad Eliason cme16@zips.uakron.edu Rafael Maia rm72@zips.uakron.edu Hugo Gruson hugo.gruson+R@normalesup.org

title: Peak shape descriptors — peakshape
code: data(teal)  peakshape(teal, select = 3)  #>           id      B3  H1 FWHM HWHM.l HWHM.r incl.min #> 1 Acrecca-02 56.4446 517   71     35     36      Yes peakshape(teal, select = 10)  #>           id     B3  H1 FWHM HWHM.l HWHM.r incl.min #> 1 Acrecca-09 7.2747 307   NA     NA     53      Yes  # Use wavelength bounds to narrow in on peak of interest peakshape(teal, select = 10, lim = c(400, 550)) #> Warning: Consider fixing “lim” in spectra with “incl.min” marked “No” to incorporate all minima in spectral curves  #>           id    B3  H1 FWHM HWHM.l HWHM.r incl.min #> 1 Acrecca-09 7.173 468   68     38     30       No

title: Process images — procimg
text: image (required) image data. Either single image array, number images stored list. Preferably result getimg(). resize integer specifying percentage resizing images, desired. E.g. 50 half size image, 200 double . rotate integer specifying angle image rotation, degrees. Images rotated around centre, linearly interpolated. scaledist integer, numeric vector equal length number images, specifying length scale image(s). Image(s) presented, user asked select either end scale corresponding input value. outline interactively specify focal object image clicking around outline. xy-coordinates resulting closed polygon saved attribute, use generating masking layer & separating animals/plants backgrounds analyses. particularly useful backgrounds complex, natural settings. reclass interactively specify area colour-classified image reclassified numeric value provided. e.g. reclass = 1, user asked select polygon image, within colour-category values changes 1. smooth polygon specified outline = TRUE smoothed using Chaikin's corner-cuting algorithm? Defaults FALSE. iterations number smoothing iterations, smooth = TRUE. Defaults 1. col color marker points /line, using interactive options. obj_dist, obj_width, eye_res blur image model visual acuity non-human animals per Caves & Johnsen (2018)'s AcuityView 2.0 algorithm. procedure requires three arguments; obj_dist real-world distance viewer focal object image image, obj_width real-world width entire image; eye_res minimum resolvable angle viewer degrees. three arguments numeric, units measurement suitable obj_dist obj_width, must match. Note flexible v2.0 implementation meaning rectangular image suitable; need square dimensions power 2. using capability, please cite Caves & Johnsen (2018), per included reference, see note . plotnew plots opened new window? Defaults FALSE. ... additional graphical parameters. Also see par().

title: Process images — procimg

title: Process images — procimg
text: several caveats considered using AcuityView algorithm. First foremost, converted image animal actually sees. example, account edge enhancement processing retina brain may alter image. , however, show spatial information can detected processed visual system. Second, converted image static, allow one assess movement may reveal presence otherwise indiscernible object. Third, AcuityView makes several assumptions Modulation Transfer Function (MTF), describes optical system affects image contrast function level detail. assumptions include MTF constant region retina views scene, circularly symmetrical, wavelength independent. full discussion details, please read Caves & Johnsen (2018).

title: Process images — procimg
text: Caves, E. M., & Johnsen, S. (2018). AcuityView: r package portraying effects visual acuity scenes observed animal. Methods Ecology Evolution, 9(3), 793-797 doi:10.1111/2041-210X.12911 . Chaikin, G. 1974. algorithm high speed curve generation. Computer Graphics Image Processing 3, 346-349.

title: Process images — procimg
code: if (interactive()) {   # Interactively add a scale to a single image   papilio <- getimg(system.file("testdata/images/butterflies/papilio.png", package = "pavo"))   papilio <- procimg(papilio, scaledist = 10)    # Interactively assign individual scales to each image,   # after slightly reducing their size (to 90% of original).   snakes <- getimg(system.file("testdata/images/snakes", package = "pavo"))   snakes <- procimg(snakes, scaledist = c(10, 14), resize = 90)    # Model the appearance of a butterfly given the reduced visual acuity of another   # animal viewer as per the AcuityView algorithm. Here our butterfly is 60 cm away,   # the image width is 10 cm, and the minimum resolvable angle of the viewer is 0.2-degrees.   tiger <- getimg(system.file("testdata/images/tiger.png", package = "pavo"))   tiger_acuity <- procimg(tiger, obj_dist = 60, obj_width = 10, eye_res = 0.2) }

title: Process spectra — procspec
text: rspecdata (required) data frame, possibly class rspec, contains column containing wavelength range, named 'wl', spectra data remaining columns. opt type processing options apply. User can select multiple options providing vector. Possibilities : "none" perform processing (default). "smooth" applies LOESS smoothing spectrum using loess.smooth(). Optimal smoothing parameter can assessed using plotsmooth(). "minimum" subtracts minimum individual spectra. "maximum" divides spectrum maximum value. "sum" divides spectrum summed values. "bin" bins spectrum specified number bins. bins argument must set. "center" centers individual spectra subtracting mean reflectance values. fixneg handle negative values. Possibilities : "none" perform negative value correction (default). "zero" sets negative values zero. "addmin" adds absolute value maximally negative values spectra reflectance wavelengths (setting minimum value zero, scaling values accordingly). span sets smoothing parameter used loess.smooth(). bins sets number equally sized wavelength bins opt = "bin".

"cie2": 2-degree colour matching functions CIE models human colour vision. Functions linear transformations 2-degree cone fundamentals Stockman & Sharpe (2000), ratified CIE (2006). "cie10": 10-degree colour matching functions CIE models human colour vision. Functions linear transformations 10-degree cone fundamentals Stockman & Sharpe (2000), ratified CIE (2006). "ctenophorus": Ornate dragon lizard Ctenophorus ornatus. "musca": Housefly Musca domestica visual system. 'drosophila': Vinegar fly Drosophila melanogaster (Sharkey et al. 2020). "pfowl": Peafowl Pavo cristatus visual system. "star": Starling Sturnus vulgaris visual system. "habronattus": Jumping spider Habronattus pyrrithrix. "rhinecanthus": Triggerfish Rhinecanthus aculeatus. achromatic sensitivity data used calculate luminance (achromatic) receptor stimulation. Options : "none": achromatic sensitivity data. "": achromatic sensitivity data. "bt.dc": Blue tit Cyanistes caeruleus double cone. "ch.dc": Chicken Gallus gallus double cone. "st.dc": Starling Sturnus vulgaris double cone. "cf.r": Canid Canis familiaris rod "md.r1": Housefly Musca domestica R1-6 photoreceptor. 'dm.r1': Vinegar fly Drosophila melanogaster R1-6 photoreceptor. "ra.dc": Triggerfish Rhinecanthus aculeatus double cone. illum illuminants. Options : "none": illuminant data. "": background spectral data. "bluesky" open blue sky. "D65": standard daylight. "forestshade" forest shade. trans Ocular transmission data. Options : "none": transmission data. "": transmission data. "bluetit": blue tit Cyanistes caeruleus ocular transmission (Hart et al. 2000). "blackbird": blackbird Turdus merula ocular transmission (Hart et al. 2000). bkg background spectra. Options : "none": background spectral data. "": background spectral data. "green": green foliage. plot spectral data plotted, returned instead (defaults FALSE)? ... additional graphical options passed plot.rspec() plot = TRUE.

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
text: Simulate naturalistic reflectance, radiance, irradiance, transmission spectrum. Curves may sigmoidal (s-shaped) /Gaussian (bell-shaped) features. Multiple Gaussian sigmoidal curves can combined single spectrum, simulate complex spectral functions.

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
code: simulate_spec(   wl_inflect = NULL,   wl_peak = NULL,   width_sig = 20,   width_gauss = 70,   skew_gauss = 0,   xlim = c(300, 700),   ylim = c(0, 100) )

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
text: wl_inflect numeric vector specifying wavelength location (nm) one inflection point(s) 'sigmoid' shaped curve, desired. wl_peak numeric vector specifying wavelength location (nm) one inflection point(s) 'Gaussian' ('bell') shaped curve, desired. width_sig numeric value vector (multiple wl_inflect values specified) specifying steepness change, sigmoidal curve(s). Required wl_peak specified. Defaults 20 nm. width_gauss numeric value vector specifying full-width half-maximum Gaussian curve(s). Required wl_peak specified. Defaults 70 nm. skew_gauss Skewness parameter controlling direction magnitude skew, simulating Gaussian curves (ignored simulating sigmoidal curves). Curves skew skew_gauss = 0 (default), right skew skew_gauss > 0, left skew skew_gauss < 0. parameter corresponds 'alpha' skew-normal distribution (Azzalini 1985). xlim vector specifying wavelength range simulated spectra. Defaults 300-700nm (c(300, 700)). ylim vector specifying minimum maximum reflectance values resulting curve. Defaults 0 - 100 % (c(0, 100)). Note: sigmoidal curves, default, move low high reflectance. high--low sigmoidal curves desired can controlled ordering values given ylim(). E.g. c(0, 100) generate low--high sigmoidal curve, whereas c(100, 0) generate high- -low curve. ordering values effect Gaussian portions final curve.

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
text: object class rspec.

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
text: Azzalini (1985). class distributions includes normal ones. Scan. J. Stat. 171-178.

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
text: Thomas White thomas.white026@gmail.com Hugo Gruson hugo.gruson+R@normalesup.org

title: Simulate a spectrum — simulate_spec
code: # Single ideal 'grey' reflectance spectrum, with 50% reflectance across 300 - 700 nm. reflect0 <- simulate_spec(ylim = c(0, 50))  # Single sigmoidal spectrum, with a low-to-high inflection at 550 nm. reflect1 <- simulate_spec(wl_inflect = 550)  # Single Gaussian spectrum, with a peak at 400 nm reflect2 <- simulate_spec(wl_peak = 400)  # Combination of both Gaussian (with peak at 340 nm) and sigmoidal (with inflection # at 560 nm) reflect3 <- simulate_spec(wl_inflect = 560, wl_peak = 340)  # Double-Gaussian peaks of differing widths reflect4 <- simulate_spec(wl_peak = c(340, 560), width_gauss = c(12, 40))  # Complex spectrum with single sigmoidal peak and multi-Gaussian peaks reflect5 <- simulate_spec(wl_inflect = 575, wl_peak = c(340, 430), width_gauss = c(20, 60))  # Simulate a set of Gaussian reflectance curves with peaks varying between 400-600nm # in increments of 10, then combine into a single rspec object, and plot the result peaks <- seq(400, 600, 10) # Peak locations reflectances <- lapply(peaks, function(p) simulate_spec(wl_peak = p)) # Simulate reflectances <- Reduce(merge, reflectances) # Combine plot(reflectances) # Plot   # Simulate a set of Gaussian reflectance curves with a single peak at 500 nm, but # with maximum reflectance varying from 30 to 90% in 10% increments, then combine # into a single rspec object, and plot the result ymax <- lapply(seq(30, 90, 10), function(x) c(0, x)) # Varying reflectance maxima reflectances2 <- lapply(ymax, function(x) simulate_spec(wl_peak = 500, ylim = x)) # Simulate reflectances2 <- Reduce(merge, reflectances2) # Combine #> Warning: column names ‘spec_p500.x’, ‘spec_p500.y’ are duplicated in the result #> Warning: column names ‘spec_p500.x’, ‘spec_p500.y’ are duplicated in the result #> Warning: column names ‘spec_p500.x’, ‘spec_p500.y’, ‘spec_p500.x’, ‘spec_p500.y’ are duplicated in the result #> Warning: column names ‘spec_p500.x’, ‘spec_p500.y’, ‘spec_p500.x’, ‘spec_p500.y’ are duplicated in the result plot(reflectances2) # Plot   # To simulate non-reflectance spectra (like irradiances or radiances), it's often useful # to explore more 'extreme' parameters. Here's a simple example which simulates # natural daylight, as represented by the D65 standard daylight spectrum. D65_real <- procspec(sensdata(illum = "D65"), opt = "smooth") # Official D65 daylight spectrum #> processing options applied: #> smoothing spectra with a span of 0.25 D65_sim <- simulate_spec(   wl_peak = 400,   width_gauss = 1300,   skew_gauss = 10,   ylim = c(0, 1) ) # Simulated D65 cor.test(D65_real$D65, D65_sim$spec_p400) # >0.99 correlation #>  #> 	Pearson's product-moment correlation #>  #> data:  D65_real$D65 and D65_sim$spec_p400 #> t = 227.71, df = 399, p-value < 2.2e-16 #> alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0 #> 95 percent confidence interval: #>  0.9953458 0.9968558 #> sample estimates: #>       cor  #> 0.9961745  #>  plot(merge(D65_real, D65_sim), lty = 1:2, ylab = "Irradiance (%)") # Merge and plot the two spectra

title: Tetrahedral colourspace — tcspace
text: Calculates coordinates colorimetric variables represent reflectance spectra avian tetrahedral color space.

title: Tetrahedral colourspace — tcspace
code: tcspace(vismodeldata)

title: Tetrahedral colourspace — tcspace
text: vismodeldata (required) quantum catch color data. Can either result vismodel() independently calculated data (form data frame four columns name 'u', 's', 'm', 'l', representing avian cones).

title: Tetrahedral colourspace — tcspace
text: data frame class colspace consisting following columns: u, s, m, l: quantum catch data used calculate remaining variables. NOTE: even visual system type V-VIS, output column labeled u. u.r, s.r, m.r, l.r: relative cone stimulation, given hue, function saturation. See Stoddard & Prum (2008) details. x, y, z: cartesian coordinates points tetrahedral color space. h.theta, h.phi: angles theta phi, radians, determining hue color. r.vec: r vector (saturation, distance achromatic center). r.max: maximum r vector achievable colour's hue. r.achieved: relative r distance achromatic center, relation maximum distance achievable (r.vec/r.max).

Endler, J. ., & Mielke, P. (2005). Comparing entire colour patterns birds see . Biological Journal Linnean Society, 86(4), 405-431.

what: Interactive plot of a tetrahedral colourspace — tcsplot
title: Interactive plot of a tetrahedral colourspace — tcsplot
text: Produces interactive 3D plot tetrahedral colourspace using OpenGL capabilities. Plots points tetrahedral colour space

title: Interactive plot of a tetrahedral colourspace — tcsplot
code: tcsplot(   tcsdata,   size = 0.02,   alpha = 1,   col = "black",   vertexsize = 0.02,   achro = TRUE,   achrosize = 0.01,   achrocol = "grey",   lwd = 1,   lcol = "lightgrey",   new = FALSE,   hspin = FALSE,   vspin = FALSE,   floor = TRUE,   gamut = FALSE )  tcspoints(tcsdata, size = 0.02, col = "black", alpha = 1)  tcsvol(   tcsdata,   type = c("convex", "alpha"),   avalue = "auto",   col = "black",   alpha = 0.2,   grid.alpha = 1,   grid = TRUE,   fill = TRUE,   lwd = 1 )

title: Interactive plot of a tetrahedral colourspace — tcsplot
text: tcsdata (required) data frame, possibly result colspace() tcspace() function, containing values 'x', 'y' 'z' coordinates columns (labeled ). size size points plot (defaults 0.02) alpha transparency points (volume fill tcsvol()) col colour points plot (defaults black) vertexsize size points vertices achro point plotted origin (defaults TRUE)? achrosize size point origin achro = TRUE (defaults 0.8). achrocol color point origin achro = TRUE (defaults 'grey'). lwd, lcol graphical parameters edges tetrahedron. new new 3D plot called (defaults FALSE)? hspin TRUE, graphic spin horizontally (around 'z' axis)(defaults FALSE) vspin TRUE, graphic spin vertically (around 'x' axis)(defaults FALSE) floor TRUE, reference xy plane plotted tetrahedron (defaults TRUE) gamut logical. polygon showing possible colours given visual system illuminant used analysis (defaults FALSE). option currently works qcatch = Qi. type accepts vector length 1 2 'p' points /'l' lines point base tetrahedron. avalue type = "alpha", alpha parameter value used compute alphashape. avalue = "auto" (default) finds use \(\alpha^*\) value defined Gruson (2020). grid.alpha transparency volume polygon grid lines grid TRUE, connects polygon outlining volume occupied points (defaults TRUE) fill TRUE, fills volume occupied points (WARNING: transparency saved properly exported using rgl.postscript)(defaults TRUE).

title: Interactive plot of a tetrahedral colourspace — tcsplot
text: tcsplot() creates 3D plot using functions package rgl, based openGL capabilities. Plot interactive can manipulated mouse (left button: rotate along 'z' axis; right button: rotate along 'x' axis; third button: zoom). tcspoints() adds points plot. Points currently plotted spheres maintain export capabilities. tcsvol() creates 3D colour volume within tcsplot object.

title: Plot a static tetrahedral colorspace — tetraplot
text: tcsdata (required) data frame, possibly result colspace() tcspace() function, containing values 'x', 'y' 'z' coordinates columns (labeled ). theta angle rotate plot xy plane (defaults 45). phi angle rotate plot yz plane (defaults 10). perspective logical, perspective forced using point size reflect distance plane view? (defaults `FALSE“) range, vert.range multiplier applied cex vert.cex, respectively, indicate size range variation reflecting distance plane view. r distance eyepoint center plotting box. high values approximate orthographic projection (defaults 1e6). See persp() details. zoom zooms (values greater 1) (values 0 1) plotting area. achro point plotted origin (defaults TRUE)? achro.line logical. achromatic line plotted? (defaults FALSE) achro.lwd, achro.lty graphical parameters achromatic coordinates. tetrahedron logical. tetrahedron plotted? (defaults TRUE) vert.cex size points vertices (defaults 1). .lwd, .lcol graphical parameters tetrahedral outline. type accepts vector length 1 2 'p' points /'l' lines point base tetrahedron. labels logical. name cone printed next corresponding vertex? gamut logical. polygon showing possible colours given visual system illuminant used analysis (defaults FALSE). option currently works qcatch = Qi. ... additional graphical options. See par().

title: Visual models — vismodel
code: vismodel(   rspecdata,   visual = c("avg.uv", "avg.v", "bluetit", "ctenophorus", "star", "pfowl", "apis",     "canis", "cie2", "cie10", "musca", "drosophila", "segment", "habronattus",     "rhinecanthus"),   achromatic = c("none", "bt.dc", "ch.dc", "st.dc", "md.r1", "dm.r1", "ra.dc", "cf.r",     "ml", "l", "all"),   illum = c("ideal", "bluesky", "D65", "forestshade"),   trans = c("ideal", "bluetit", "blackbird"),   qcatch = c("Qi", "fi", "Ei"),   bkg = c("ideal", "green"),   vonkries = FALSE,   scale = 1,   relative = TRUE )

title: Visual models — vismodel
text: rspecdata (required) data frame, possibly class rspec, contains column containing wavelength range, named 'wl', spectra data remaining columns. visual visual system used. Options : data frame one produced containing sensmodel(), containing user-defined sensitivity data receptors involved colour vision. data frame must contain 'wl' column range wavelengths included, sensitivity cone column. 'apis': Honeybee Apis mellifera. 'avg.uv': average avian UV system (default). 'avg.v': average avian V system. 'bluetit': Blue tit Cyanistes caeruleus. 'canis': Canid Canis familiaris. 'cie2': 2-degree colour matching functions CIE models human colour vision. Functions linear transformations 2-degree cone fundamentals Stockman & Sharpe (2000), ratified CIE (2006). 'cie10': 10-degree colour matching functions CIE models human colour vision. Functions linear transformations 10-degree cone fundamentals Stockman & Sharpe (2000), ratified CIE (2006). 'ctenophorus': Ornate dragon lizard Ctenophorus ornatus. 'musca': Housefly Musca domestica. 'drosophila': Vinegar fly Drosophila melanogaster (Sharkey et al. 2020). 'pfowl': Peafowl Pavo cristatus. 'segment': Generic tetrachromat 'viewer' use segment analysis Endler (1990). 'star': Starling Sturnus vulgaris. 'habronattus': Jumping spider Habronattus pyrrithrix. 'rhinecanthus': Triggerfish Rhinecanthus aculeatus. achromatic sensitivity data used calculate luminance (achromatic) receptor stimulation. Either vector containing sensitivity single receptor, one options: 'none': achromatic stimulation calculated (default). 'bt.dc': Blue tit Cyanistes caeruleus double cone. 'ch.dc': Chicken Gallus gallus double cone. 'st.dc': Starling Sturnus vulgaris double cone. 'md.r1': Housefly Musca domestica R1-6 photoreceptor. 'dm.r1': Vinegar fly Drosophila melanogaster R1-6 photoreceptor. 'ra.dc': Triggerfish Rhinecanthus aculeatus double cone. 'cf.r': Canid Canis familiaris cone. 'ml': summed response two longest-wavelength photoreceptors. 'l': longest-wavelength photoreceptor. '': summed response photoreceptors. illum either vector containing illuminant, one options: 'ideal': homogeneous illuminance 1 across wavelengths (default) 'bluesky' open blue sky. 'D65': standard daylight. 'forestshade' forest shade. trans either vector containing ocular environmental transmission spectra, one options: 'ideal': homogeneous transmission 1 across wavelengths (default) 'bluetit': blue tit Cyanistes caeruleus ocular transmission (Hart et al. 2000). 'blackbird': blackbird Turdus merula ocular transmission (Hart et al. 2000). qcatch quantal catch metric return. Options : 'Qi': Quantum catch photoreceptor (default) 'fi': Quantum catch according Fechner's law (signal receptor channel proportional logarithm quantum catch) 'Ei': Hyperbolic-transformed quantum catch, Ei = Qi / (Qi + 1). bkg background spectrum. Note effect vonkries = FALSE. Either vector containing spectral data, one options: 'ideal': homogeneous illuminance 1 across wavelengths (default). 'green': green foliage. vonkries logical. von Kries colour correction transformation applied? (defaults FALSE). scale value illuminant multiplied. Useful illuminant relative value (.e. transformed maximum 1 percentage), correspond quantum flux units (μmol.s-1.m-2). Useful values , example, 500 (dim light) 10000 (bright illumination). Note vonkries = TRUE transformation effect. relative relative quantum catches returned (.e. colour space model? Defaults TRUE).

title: Visual models — vismodel
code: # Dichromat (dingo) data(flowers) vis.dingo <- vismodel(flowers, visual = "canis") di.dingo <- colspace(vis.dingo, space = "di")  # Trichromat (honeybee) data(flowers) vis.bee <- vismodel(flowers, visual = "apis") tri.bee <- colspace(vis.bee, space = "tri")  # Tetrachromat (blue tit) data(sicalis) vis.bluetit <- vismodel(sicalis, visual = "bluetit") tcs.bluetit <- colspace(vis.bluetit, space = "tcs")  # Tetrachromat (starling), receptor-noise model data(sicalis) vis.star <- vismodel(sicalis, visual = "star", achromatic = "bt.dc", relative = FALSE) dist.star <- coldist(vis.star, achromatic = TRUE) #> Calculating noise-weighted Euclidean distances and noise-weighted luminance contrasts  # Estimate quantum catches using a custom trichromatic visual phenotype custom <- sensmodel(c(330, 440, 550)) names(custom) <- c("wl", "s", "m", "l") vis.custom <- vismodel(flowers, visual = custom) tri.custom <- colspace(vis.custom, space = "tri")

title: Colour volume overlap — voloverlap
text: colsp1, colsp2 (required) data frame, possibly result colspace() function, containing values 'x', 'y' (possibly 'z') coordinates columns (labeled ) type "convex", colour volume plotted using convex hull "alpha", plotted using alphashapes. avalue type = alpha, alpha parameter values colsp1 colsp2 respectively compute alphashapes. Can numeric length one value used cases. avalue = "auto" (default) finds use \(\alpha^*\) value defined Gruson (2020). plot logical. volumes points plotted? (defaults FALSE). works tetrahedral colourspaces moment. interactive logical. TRUE, uses rgl engine interactive plotting; FALSE static plot generated. col vector length 3 colours (order) first volume, second volume, overlap. fill logical. two volumes filled plot? (defaults FALSE) new logical. new plot window called? FALSE, volumes overlap plotted current plot (defaults TRUE). nsamp type = "alpha", number points sampled Monte Carlo computation. Stoddard & Stevens(2011) use around 750,000 points, fewer might required depending degree overlap. psize type = "alpha" plot = TRUE, sets size plot points used Monte Carlo computation. lwd plot = TRUE, sets line width volume grids. ... additional arguments passed plot. See vol()

title: Colour volume overlap — voloverlap
text: Calculates overlap volumes defined two set points colourspace. volume overlap given relative : vsmallest volume overlap divided smallest defined two input sets colour points. Thus, one volumes entirely contained within , overlap vsmallest = 1. vboth volume overlap divided combined volume input sets colour points. type = "alpha", used, output different: s_in1, s_in2 number sampled points fall within volumes individually. s_inboth number sampled points fall within volumes. s_ineither number points fall within either volumes. psmallest proportion points fall within volumes divided number points fall within smallest volume. pboth proportion points fall within volumes divided total number points fall within volumes.

title: Colour volume overlap — voloverlap
text: Stoddard & Stevens (2011) originally obtained volume overlap Monte Carlo simulations points within range volumes, obtaining frequency simulated values fall inside volumes defined sets colour points. Stoddard & Stevens (2011) also return value overlap relative one volumes (case, host species). However, applications value may one expects obtain (1) two volumes differ considerably size, (2) one volumes entirely contained within . reason, also report volume relative union two input volumes, may adequate cases.

title: Colour volume overlap — voloverlap
code: data(sicalis) tcs.sicalis.C <- subset(colspace(vismodel(sicalis)), "C") tcs.sicalis.T <- subset(colspace(vismodel(sicalis)), "T") tcs.sicalis.B <- subset(colspace(vismodel(sicalis)), "B")  # Convex hull volume voloverlap(tcs.sicalis.T, tcs.sicalis.B, type = "convex") #>           vol1         vol2   overlapvol vsmallest      vboth #> 1 5.183721e-06 6.281511e-06 6.904074e-07 0.1331876 0.06407598 voloverlap(tcs.sicalis.T, tcs.sicalis.C, type = "convex", plot = TRUE)  #>           vol1         vol2 overlapvol vsmallest vboth #> 1 5.183721e-06 4.739152e-06          0         0     0 voloverlap(tcs.sicalis.T, tcs.sicalis.C, type = "convex", plot = TRUE, col = seq_len(3))  #>           vol1         vol2 overlapvol vsmallest vboth #> 1 5.183721e-06 4.739152e-06          0         0     0  # Alpha-shape volume if (require("alphashape3d")) {   voloverlap(tcs.sicalis.T, tcs.sicalis.B, type = "alpha", avalue = 1) } #>           vol1         vol2 s_in1 s_in2 s_inboth s_ineither psmallest pboth #> 1 5.183721e-06 6.231493e-06    12    15        3         24      0.25 0.125

title: pavo 2.10.0
text: rimg2cimg() function removed favour custom .cimg() method. jndrot() extension jnd2xyz() adjusted trichromats allow rotations 2D plane. now, 3D rotations allowed result projected back 2D meant output longer representing JNDs distances. rotate = TRUE default jnd2xyz(), recommend re-run jnd2xyz() computation trichromats. tests, results stay qualitatively similar specific values may change.

title: pavo 2.10.0
text: default values arguments explorespec() sensmodel() now explicit function definition. .rspec() now works box tibble, rather requiring users pass standard data.frame. messages tcspace() converted warnings consistency internal colspace functions error messages reorder, means errors produced inputs invalid multiple reasons may appear different order previous versions. pavo now uses R 4.1 (released 2021) minimum required R version.

title: pavo 2.10.0
text: dependency viridisLite package removed favour recent base R functions

title: pavo 2.9.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-09-24

title: pavo 2.9.0
text: Added new function simulate_spec(), allows flexible simulation naturalistic spectra (inc. reflectance, irradiance, radiance, absorbance). See ?simulate_spec examples information, handbook discussion. plot.rspec() now accepts logical labels argument (labels.cex), control whether text labels identifying spectrum added outer plot margins. previously available, required, ‘stacked’ plot types, now optional ‘overlay’ (default) ‘stacked’ spectral plots. wlmin wlmax arguments summary.rspec() deprecated favour single lim argument, consistency across functions.

title: pavo 2.9.0
text: summary.rspec() rewritten efficiency, now calculates required variables subset used. result, function also slightly slower (0.5 x) calculating full set variables, much faster (10 x) calculating subset. Removed start-message. Removed previously-deprecated margins argument various colourspace plots. Replace rgl.triangles triangles3d() internally avoid deprecation issue. Fixed bug categorical colourspace, now returns sensible category values x /y equal 0.

title: pavo 2.8.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-16

title: pavo 2.8.0
text: Updated documentation fix broken HTML5 equation rendering Line width legend aggplot() (specified lwd) now consistent line width plot (#235) procspec(spec, opt = "smooth") now works correctly uninterpolated spectra. Previously, causing shift spectra towards long-wavelengths (#234). coldist() now returns Euclidean distances given data ciexyz model. .rspec() now preserves numeric column names converting tibble.

title: pavo 2.7.1
text: CRAN release: 2021-09-21

title: pavo 2.7.1
text: Minor release avoid breaking changes tests.

title: pavo 2.7.0
text: CRAN release: 2021-03-23

title: pavo 2.7.0
text: now possible filter images according AcuityView 2.0 algorithm (Caves et al. 2018) order model visual acuity animals, prior analysis. functionality implemented procimg(), details examples available function’s help documentation vignette. Added argument raw bootcoldist(). TRUE, full raw list bootstrapped colour-distances returned (equal length number replicates specified boot.n), rather summary statistics returned default. Added visual phenotype Vinegar fly Drosophila melanogaster (Sharkey et al. 2020). See ?vismodel() ?sensdata() instructions selecting . coldist() now uses package farver calculating CIE2000 colour distances points CIELab CIELch spaces.

title: pavo 2.7.0
text: Fixed bug procimg() fail using resize/rotate followed options, single images. vignettes moved https://book.colrverse.com/ now use book format Fixed bug plot.colspace(gamut = TRUE) (well triplot(), tcsplot(), tetraplot()) incorrectly display "Max gamut plotted." fail plot max gamut time. Fixed recent bug whereby D65 illuminant expressed units radiant flux, default. instead converted photon flux (umol.s-1.m-2). Added informative error message raw quantum catch estimates < 1, attempt made calculate colour distances receptor-noise model using noise = 'quantum'. Taking root negative values following log-transformation, required noise = 'quantum', previously produce uninformative error, rectified. margins argument deprecated cie, coc, hexagon, segment, projplot, di-, tri-, tetra-chromatic plots. causing problems later adding points plots, margin-handling best left user anyway. default plots may therefore look slightly different, margins can adjusted taste using standard par(mar = c()) pathway. Fixed bug bootcoldist() run supplied receptor-noise model arguments (n, weber, weber.ref), even running receptor-noise model. Fixed bug bootcoldist() sometimes fail given data colourspace models containing lots negative coordinate values. particularly common hexagon model. Improved safety error handling adjacent().

title: pavo 2.6.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-12-18

title: pavo 2.6.1
text: Minor fix vignette avoid installation issues. options() par() now always set locally, including vignettes examples, prevent spillover changes user session

title: pavo 2.6.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-12-09

title: pavo 2.6.0
text: bootcoldist() adjacent() now use random number generator generates statistically sound values, even ran parallel. output functions thus expected slightly change, even set seed . alphashape3d package moved Suggests, means installed automatically install pavo CRAN need install need (vol(type = "alpha"), vol(type = "alpha") voloverlap(type = "alpha"))

title: pavo 2.5.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-11-12

title: pavo 2.5.0
text: Add ability compute colour volume using alphashapes instead convex hulls. functions vol(), tcsvol() voloverlap() gain new argument type = c("convex", "alpha") decide want compute colour volume. Please refer vignette vignette("pavo-5-alphashapes",    package = "pavo") information. result, argument order 3 function changed. Check documentation update scripts accordingly. function summary.colspace() also gains additional column returns colour volume computed alpha-shape parameter alpha* case tcs objects.

title: pavo 2.5.0
text: getimg() now imports image files uppercase extensions (e.g., JPG PNG), produced camera brands processing software. Maximum quantum catches computation (data.maxqcatches attribute) now works segment “visual model” well. side effect, removes warning occurred users ran vismodel(..., visual = "segment"). sensmodel() now accepts argument sensnames, specifying names resulting sensitivity curves --fly. CIE models now accept data created outside vismodel(), allowing users specify illuminant viewer sensitivity function used estimating XYZ values (via illum visual arguments colspace()). bootcoldist() now laxer argument checks accept objects neither vismodel colspace objects. means can now use function quantum catches dataframe obtained outside pavo, MICA toolbox. summary.colspace() now prints explicit error argument value multiple number rows colspace object (.e., number spectra) Added continuous measure hue output categorical model Troje (1993) teal example dataset columns renamed add additional zero front single digit numbers, column names now sort correct order default. small negative values built-visual system data corrected . .rspec() now lenient wavelength trimming interp = FALSE now works even specified lims correspond actual wl values input object.

title: pavo 2.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-02-08

title: pavo 2.4.0
text: Fixed bug introduced version 2.3.0 gave wrong values S1UV S1V summary.rspec(). several plot() functions colspace (triplot(), tcsplot(), tetraplot()) gain new gamut argument plot maximum gamut given visual system illuminant. summary.colspace() also now returns maximum colour volume given visual system illuminant can use compare realised volume given dataset. information PR #180. parallel processing now relies future package, offers windows high performance computing (HPC) environments support. progress bar produced progressr package can customised well. consequence, cores argument getspec(), adjacent() classify() deprecated.

title: pavo 2.4.0
text: fixed plotting bug introduced version 2.3.0 required run projplot() twice background grid displayed. fixed bug summary.colspace() NULL returned instead summary.data.frame() non-tcs colourspaces. fix partial matching warnings examples bootcooldist() package new website pavo.colrverse.com fixed bug coldist()prevented calculation achromatic contrast using custom quantum catch data
